data.title: StrInv
data.solution:
import re

# Look for a function call.
m = re.search(r'StrInv\("((?:.*?[^\\](?:\\\\)*|))"\)', input())

if m is None:
    print("(nothing to reverse)")
elif m.group(1) == "":
    print("(nothing to display)")
else:
    # Unescape backslashes and quotes.
    param = re.sub(r'\\(.)', r'\1', m.group(1))
    print(param[::-1])
data.statement:
On CASIO calculators, the BASIC language implementation has an <<StrInv>> function that reverses a string's order. This challenge is about reimplementing this method, while taking care of string quoting.

<<You are provided with a message that may contain a single StrInv function call, and if this is the case, you must compute and print the result.>> The function call will always start with {{StrInv("}} and end with {{")}}. If the string contains any {{"}} or {{\}} character, it will be preceded with a {{\}} character.

If an StrInv function call is present in the message, you must determine the string, reverse it and print it. For example:

* {{StrInv("abc")}} will produce {{cba}} as a result.
* {{StrInv("a\"b\\c")}} will produce {{c\b"a}} as a result.
* {{StrInv("a (\"bc\")")}} will produce {{)"cb"( a}} as a result.

If the StrInv parameter is the empty string, you must print {{(nothing to display)}}.

If no StrInv function call is present in the message, you must print {{(nothing to reverse)}}.

testCases.title: An StrInv call appears!
testCases.testIn: I wonder what StrInv("world") actually produces.

testCases.title: An StrInv call appears!
testCases.testIn: I see, but what about StrInv("abc")?

testCases.title: No StrInv in sight!
testCases.testIn: I don't have a CASIO calculator.

testCases.title: It's another function call!
testCases.testIn: You can actually compute the length using StrLen("your string").

testCases.title: It's another function call!
testCases.testIn: I don't understand, why doesn't StrInverse("my string") work?

testCases.title: It's trying to escape!
testCases.testIn: Oh no, I fear the result of StrInv("\\\"aibohphobia\"")!

testCases.title: Where does it end?
testCases.testIn: Can you detect the end of StrInv("just something (you know, \"something\\\")") correctly? (haha, "correctly")

testCases.title: Empty input
testCases.testIn: My soul is the result of StrInv("")

testCases.title: Unterminated function call
testCases.testIn: A good story always has an end, StrInv("but this one doesn't (source: \"me\")

testCases.title: Unterminated function call
testCases.testIn: And it goes StrInv("on, and on, and on, and on, and on (\"and on\"), and on...

data.outputDescription: <<First line:>> The StrInv result, {{(nothing to display)}} or {{(nothing to reverse)}}.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

On CASIO calculators, the BASIC language implementation has an StrInv function that reverses a string's order. This challenge is about reimplementing this method, while taking care of string quoting.

You are provided with a message that may contain a single StrInv function call, and if this is the case, you must compute and print the result. The function call will always start with StrInv(" and end with "). If the string contains any " or \ character, it will be preceded with a \ character.

If an StrInv function call is present in the message, you must determine the string, reverse it and print it. For example:

* StrInv("abc") will produce cba as a result.
* StrInv("a\"b\\c") will produce c\b"a as a result.
* StrInv("a (\"bc\")") will produce )"cb"( a as a result.

If the StrInv parameter is the empty string, you must print (nothing to display).

If no StrInv function call is present in the message, you must print (nothing to reverse).
Input
First line: The message to process.
Output
First line: The StrInv result, (nothing to display) or (nothing to reverse).
Constraints
0 < length(message) < 250
Example
Input
I wonder what StrInv("world") actually produces.
Output
dlrow
